I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This capacity development technical assistance (TA)1 was first included in the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) country operations business plan for Viet Nam, 2012–2014.2 The TA 
will  support  the  National  Microfinance  Development  Strategy,  2011–2020,3 which  aims  to 
establish legal, policy, regulatory, and supervisory frameworks for microfinance; enhance the 
operational capacity of microfinance institutions (MFIs); and strengthen the supervisory capacity 
in microfinance. The TA will complement ADB’s ongoing Microfinance Development Program4 in 
supporting  the  government’s  policy  reform  agenda  to  improve  the  quality,  accessibility, 
efficiency,  and  competitiveness  of  microfinance  in  line  with  the  National  Microfinance 
Development Strategy. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Since 2001, the Government of Viet Nam has supported the development of formal 
private sector MFIs to expand their outreach to low-income households nationwide, recognizing 
their potential to serve clients more sustainably, effectively, and efficiently than existing state-led 
operations. The government initiative to nurture regulated MFIs has been supported by ADB 
since 2001 through a series of TA projects5 to develop a legal and supervisory framework within 
which  semiformal  microfinance  programs  have  been  encouraged  to  become  formal  MFIs 
licensed and supervised by the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV).  
 
3.  Transforming  semiformal  microfinance  programs  into  formal  MFIs  requires  that 
institutions and capacity be broadly upgraded in line  with the globally accepted prudential 
requirements applicable to deposit-taking financial institutions. At the same time, capacity to 
supervise MFIs should be adequately established to ensure high-quality microfinance services 
to existing and potential clients in need of diverse financial services. Since 2009, an ADB grant 
project  financed  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)6 has  enhanced  the 
operational capacity of MFIs and supervisory capacity of the SBV benefiting 29 MFIs and SBV 
microfinance  regulators  through  12  sets  of  training  sessions  and  3  series  of  supervision 
workshops. It also supported five MFIs’ licensing to become formal deposit-taking MFIs by 
providing supplementary matching funds for their institutional development, as required by SBV 
licensing requirements.  
 
4.  While  the  importance  of  training  has  been  widely  recognized,  institutionalizing  and 
sustainably conducting training remains a challenge. Operational and supervisory capacity in 
microfinance will need strengthening both in depth and in breadth, in theory and in practice. This 
is confirmed by the growing number of MFIs that have participated in capacity development 
under the JFPR project (footnote 6), in response to their increasingly unmet training needs.

Likewise, the need to build supervisory capacity has risen along with the growing number of 
microfinance providers preparing to become formal MFIs. The completion of the JFPR project in 
December  2012  left  an  acute  need  to  further  roll  out  well-structured,  comprehensive 
microfinance training programs for both operators and supervisors.   
 
5.  As of December 2011, clients of licensed and unlicensed MFIs amounted to only 5% of 
all  microfinance  clients.  However,  MFI  operations  have  been  growing  rapidly  with  ADB 
assistance in recent years. The JFPR project saw five MFI participants in project training and 
recipients  of  supplementary  matching  funds  increase  their  client  numbers  by  92%,  credit 
provision by 180%, and savings mobilized by 364% over the 2-year implementation period. 
Other MFIs participating in the JFPR project have increased their outreach to clients during the 
same period by 20%. Although they still hold only a small share of the microfinance market, 
MFIs can grow further under the National Microfinance Development Strategy, which recognizes 
that strengthening the operational and supervisory capacity of MFIs is a key to robust sector 
development.  
 
6.  On 5 July 2012, ADB approved the Microfinance Development Program (MDP), which 
includes  a  policy-based  loan  amounting  to  $40  million  for  subprogram  1,  and  policy  and 
advisory TA amounting to $0.5 million (footnote 4). The MDP supports the development of a 
market-oriented microfinance sector to improve access to formal financial services for the poor, 
especially in rural areas. It was formulated to promote fair competition among diverse financial 
institutions and to support the private sector’s role in microfinance, thereby gradually curtailing 
the  government’s  direct  involvement.  To  this  end,  the  MDP  addresses  four  broad  areas:  
(i)  policy  and  regulatory  reforms,  (ii)  supervisory  capacity  building,  (iii) the  operational  and 
institutional  development  of financial  institutions  involved  in microfinance;  and (iv) financial 
infrastructure development. Under an improved policy and regulatory framework, strengthened 
operational  and  supervisory  capacity  will  enhance  the  sustainability  and  outreach  of 
microfinance services. State-owned financial institutions that lend to low-income households 
and microenterprises and are funded by the government budget will be guided to become self-
sustaining financial institutions operating  by market principles. The MDP seeks to develop 
financial infrastructure through formal microfinance training, advocacy of financial literacy and 
sustainable microfinance and customer protection, and credit information exchange systems. 
 
7.  The policy and advisory TA (PATA) attached to the MDP helped the government achieve 
in  October  2012  key  policy  actions  under  subprogram  2,  which  is  scheduled  for  Board 
consideration in 2014. The attached TA (i) helped formulate MFI regulations, (ii) studied fiscal 
and regulatory incentives for MFIs, (iii) developed a microfinance credit information exchange 
system, and (iv) formulated a development framework for micro insurance. To ensure effective 
and efficient MDP implementation, the government and ADB agreed that parallel TA to develop 
the capacity of microfinance operations and supervision was necessary to complement the 
MDP’s policy dialogue and the policy advice offered under the attached TA. As the National 
Microfinance Development Strategy is implemented with broad stakeholder participation,7 such 
capacity development TA should cover not only MFIs but other potentially sustainable financial 
institutions involved in microfinance, such as the Vietnam Bank for Social Policies (VBSP), the 
Central People’s Credit Fund (CCF), and people’s credit funds (PCFs). Supervisory training 
should  be  provided  as well  to  (i) the  SBV  on  prudential regulation  of financial  institutions 
involved  in  microfinance,  (ii)  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  on  improved  public  finance 
management through the VBSP, and (iii) the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) on

formulating the microfinance development policy in the context of national economic planning. 
The  PATA  also  recognized  the  need  to  strengthen  operational  and  supervisory  capacity 
regarding micro insurance, along with the government’s development policy and regulatory 
framework, both of which are being formulated under the PATA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
8.  The TA will support ongoing government efforts to develop a vibrant microfinance sector 
with diverse financial institutions operating in a harmonized prudential environment.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The  impact  will  be  more  inclusive  financial  services  achieved  through  expanded 
microfinance.  The  outcome  will  be  enhanced  operational  and  supervisory  capacity  in 
microfinance.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA will have four outputs: (i) training provided to MFIs, the CCF, PCFs, and the 
VBSP; (ii) training provided to the SBV, MOF, and MPI; (iii) the establishment of a formal 
microfinance  training  network;  and  (iv)  opportunities  for  supervisors  and  microfinance 
practitioners to share knowledge of international best practices.  
 
11.  Training for financial institutions involved in microfinance. The TA will further roll 
out  training  under  the  previous  JFPR  grant  project  to  formalize  an  increased  number  of 
semiformal microfinance operations. In addition to the previous syllabus, new topics like product 
development, financial literacy for clients, and social performance management will be covered 
in response to growing needs.8 Training will be conducted in partnership with existing training 
institutes including the Microfinance Center at the Banking Academy,9 the training institutes of 
large MFIs, and community-based resource centers. The training of trainers will be practiced to 
the  extent  that  it  maximizes  training  performance.  The  TA  will  also  support  capacity 
development for micro insurance providers based on the rules and regulations formulated by the 
TA attached to the MDP (para. 7). Micro insurance training will raise awareness of the need to 
promote  micro  insurance  among  stakeholders,  improve  the  governance  structure,  and 
strengthen  the  operational  and  institutional  capacity  of  micro  insurance  providers  to 
appropriately protect low-income policy holders against contingent risks. The TA will develop 
capacity in the VBSP, the CCF, and PCFs toward developing sustainable market-oriented 
financial institutions in line with the policy actions called for by the MDP, focusing on institutional 
reform,  improved  banking  skills,  and  raising  stakeholders’  awareness  of  market-oriented 
microfinance.  
 
12.  Training for supervisory agencies. Supervisory training for the SBV will be based on a 
supervision manual elaborating newly formulated implementing rules and regulations (IRRs) 
pertaining to MFI operations under provisions of the Credit Institutions Law, 2010. The IRRs are 
formulated by the MDP and its attached TA and are benchmarked to the supervision standards 
of the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor and regional best practices. Training will be 
                                                
8 The syllabus included  governance, strategic planning, business planning, financial management, risk management, 
portfolio and delinquency management, financial accounting, performance indicators and standards, financial and 
social performance assessment, human resource management, and business planning for formalization. 
9  The Banking Academy is a professional training and research institute in economics, finance, and banking under 
the auspices of the SBV. Its Microfinance Center is being established with the assistance of the MDP.

4 
extended  to  central  and  provincial  institutions  alike  in  line  with  decentralized  financial 
supervision  in  Viet  Nam.  SBV  supervisory  training  on  CCF/PCFs  will  be  based  on  newly 
formulated  IRRs  pertaining  to  provisions  of  the  Credit  Institutions  Law  on  the  CCF 
transformation and PCF operations. The IRRs are formulated by MDP and its attached TA, 
benchmarked to the supervision standards of the World Council of Credit Unions and regional 
best practices. The Credit Institutions Law mandated the SBV to prudentially supervise the 
VBSP. Supervisory training for the SBV will be designed and implemented based on prudential 
requirements applicable to the VBSP, as formulated by the MDP  and its TA. Supervisory 
training for the MOF will be designed and implemented from the perspective of public finance 
management, and for the MPI from the perspective of macroeconomic planning. Supervisory 
training in micro insurance will be provided to the Insurance Supervisory Authority under the 
MOF. 
 
13.  Establishment of a formal microfinance training network. The TA will play a pivotal 
role in establishing a national network of formal microfinance training to enhance the capacity of 
the microfinance industry in line with globally adopted standards to secure financial soundness 
through profitability, liquidity, solvency, efficiency, and outreach. The TA will develop training 
modules based on the operational and regulatory standards of the Consultative Group to Assist 
the Poor and aligned with the Basel III Accord, the latest global prudential standards applicable 
to banks. Training modules will be published, and courses offered by the TA will be harmonized 
through  consultation  with  partner  training  institutes.  A  certification  system  will  be  explored 
through  consultations  with  stakeholders,  including  the  SBV,  the  Banking  Academy’s 
Microfinance Center, the Vietnam Microfinance Working Group, partner training institutes, MFIs, 
and financial institutions involved in microfinance, to standardize training and maintain integrity 
in the industry. 
 
14.  Knowledge-sharing opportunities for supervisors and microfinance practitioners 
on  international  best  practices.  As  the  Viet  Nam  microfinance  sector  sees  state-led 
operations  gradually  transferred  to  market-oriented  financial  institutions  that  compete  with 
emerging private sector MFIs, there has emerged an acute shortage of qualified microfinance 
supervisors  familiar  with  the  distinctive  features  of  microfinance  operations.  Learning  from 
overseas  supervision  practices  is  one  of  the  most  effective  ways  to  enhance  supervisory 
capacity in microfinance. The TA will encourage global knowledge sharing by  providing to 
microfinance supervisors practical training in partnership with supervisory agencies in other 
countries  that  have  successfully  promoted  microfinance  supervision  in  line  with  globally 
recognized  principles.  On  their  part,  microfinance-operating  financial  institutions  can  better 
achieve their growth potential by learning good practices for operations, management, and 
governance in overseas markets (as the domestic sector offers few such cases) and adapting 
the experiences of these exemplars to the national setting. The TA will promote regional and 
global knowledge sharing for microfinance operators and regulators alike. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,200,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, and other in-kind 
contributions. Participating financial institutions involved in microfinance will directly finance 
$20,000 equivalent for training participation.  TA cost estimates and the financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The executing agency will be the SBV, which will establish a project management unit to 
coordinate TA implementing agencies and oversee implementation. The implementing agencies 
will  be  the  SBV,  MOF,  MPI,  CCF,  and  the  MFIs  and  PCFs  whose  participation  will  be 
determined during implementation. The SBV’s capacity to effectively and efficiently manage 
ADB  loan,  technical  assistance,  and  grant  projects  has  been  proven  by  its  successful 
implementation of past ADB assistance, including recent projects on microfinance: the JFPR 
project Formalizing Microfinance Institutions (footnote 6) and the TA Preparing the Microfinance 
Sector  Development  Program  (footnote  3).  All  implementing  agencies  have  successfully 
implemented projects funded by international development partners including ADB. The TA will 
begin in September 2013 and be implemented over 48 months to end in September 2017.  
 
17.  The  TA  will  provide  18  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and 
27 person-months of national consulting services through a consulting firm, which will monitor 
and report on the TA activities and outputs. The consulting firm will be chosen by quality- and 
cost-based  selection  using  simplified technical proposals. The  consultants  will  work  on  an 
intermittent basis, engaged in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will accord with ADB's 
Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Equipment  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). Appendix 3 provides the consultant terms of reference.  
 
18.  The consultants will prepare (i) an inception report including a detailed work program to 
be submitted within 1 month of the start of the TA and to be discussed at the initial review 
meeting with ADB, the SBV, and the implementing agencies; (ii) quarterly progress reports;  
(iii) a midterm report within 10 months of TA inception; (iv) a draft final report covering progress, 
TA achievements, and requirements for future assistance 1 month before TA completion; and 
(v) a final report 1 month after the receipt of comments from the government and ADB on the 
draft final report. Training reports will be included in these reports as appropriate. Regular and 
ad hoc review missions will be conducted as necessary by ADB upon endorsement of the SBV 
to monitor and report on major project activities. The government will provide inputs in kind, 
including staff time, facilities for TA administration, and coordination to host training and other 
events  related  to  the  TA  activities.  Uploading  TA  outputs  to  government  websites  will  be 
undertaken and/or arranged by the SBV. An advance payment facility can be established at the 
SBV to facilitate the implementation of training and workshops under the TA. Both ADB and the 
SBV will oversee TA implementation and offer necessary inputs, coordination, and consultations 
with stakeholders for a successful TA result. TA consultants will make inputs as outlined in, but 
not limited to the terms of reference, to support the overall implementation of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction  for  Strengthening  Microfinance  Sector  Operations  and  Supervision,  and  hereby 
reports the action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  18  person-months  of  international  consulting 
services and 27 person-months of national consulting services through a consulting firm, which 
will support, monitor, and report on the consultants’ activities and outputs. 
 
A.   International Consultants 
 
2.  Microfinance  development  specialist  and  team  leader  (8  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist will have a postgraduate degree in banking or finance and at least 
10  years  of recognized  professional  experience  in  microfinance, focusing  on  capacity  and 
institutional  development  for  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs),  MFI  development  policy  and 
supervisory and regulatory frameworks, and project management. Experience in Southeast Asia, 
especially in microfinance development in Viet Nam, is desirable. Working with the project 
management unit (PMU), the specialist will: 
 
(i)  oversee and manage the planning and implementation of training and workshops 
designed under the TA; 
(ii)  monitor how well TA activities have achieved the policy actions in the policy 
matrix of subprogram 2 of the Microfinance Development Program; 
(iii)   guide and assist the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) in establishing supervisory 
frameworks  for  MFIs,  the  Central  Credit  Fund  (CCF),  people’s  credit  funds 
(PCFs), and the Vietnam Bank for Social Policies (VBSP) and in implementing 
risk-based  supervision  through  effective  and  efficient  examinations  to  be 
conducted on and off site, centrally and provincially; 
(iv)  guide  and  assist  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  in  establishing  a  VBSP 
supervisory framework from the perspectives of public finance management and 
the financial management of state-owned banks; 
(v)   guide and assist the microfinance programs in transition to become licensed 
MFIs, the CCF, PCFs, and the VBSP in accordance with SBV licensing and 
regulatory requirements, including the preparation of business plans, corporate 
governance  mechanisms,  accounting  systems,  management  information 
systems, information technology systems, and internal controls; the formulation 
and  implementation  of  policies  and  operational  manuals;  credit,  asset,  and 
liability  management;  and  other  microfinance  best  practices  for  sustainable 
growth and outreach to the poor;  
(vi)   lead a TA initiative to establish a national network of formal microfinance training 
through  consultation  among  stakeholders  including  the  Banking  Academy’s 
Microfinance Center, the SBV, training institutes, MFIs, the CCF, and the VBSP, 
and organize workshops to promote the national microfinance training network 
and reach agreement among participating parties on critical issues including the 
development of a certification system; 
(vii)   provide day-to-day mentoring support to the PMU on project management and 
the implementation of TA activities, monitoring, financial transactions, and related 
activities  as necessary; and 
(viii)  guide and manage the inputs of the other consultants, take lead responsibility for 
preparing  and  submitting  to  ADB  through  the  PMU  the  inception,  quarterly 
progress,  midterm,  draft  final,  and  final  reports,  incorporating  as  appropriate 
comments and contributions from the SBV, the PMU, and other consultants. The 
successful submission of the reports will be linked to the consultant’s payment 
milestones.

10  Appendix 3 
3.  Microfinance  training specialist  (6 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will 
have a postgraduate degree in banking or finance or a development-related subject and at least 
7  years  of  recognized  professional  experience  in  training,  microfinance,  and  project 
management. Prior microfinance training experience is required. Experience in Southeast Asia, 
especially knowledge of Viet Nam’s microfinance sector, is desirable. Working with the team 
leader and the PMU, the specialist will: 
 
(i)  formulate the training and workshops on microfinance operation and supervision, 
including the scope of activities and a detailed implementation plan, through 
training needs assessments and consultations with partner training institutes and 
financial supervisory agencies both at home and abroad; 
(ii)  conduct series of trainings and workshops and provide day-to-day support to 
meet  the  specific  training  requirements  of  the  microfinance  operators  and 
supervisors participating in training, including on-the-job mentoring in all aspects 
of microfinance operations, supervision, and regulations, as necessary; 
(iii)  review SBV microfinance supervision manuals and guidelines, including on-site 
and  off-site  monitoring  and  reporting  requirements,  and  recommend 
improvements (the improved supervision manuals and guidelines will be used in 
a series of supervision trainings and workshops for SBV staff to enhance their 
supervisory capacity through examinations and reporting); 
(iv)  assess and consolidate the training needs of microfinance practitioners (boards, 
management, and staff) on governance, accounting, information systems, credit 
management,  risk  management,  regulatory  and  reporting  requirements,  and 
other practices needed for a sound microfinance operation; 
(v)  develop a training plan and coordinate to engage partner microfinance training 
institutes in the delivery of practical training courses tailored to the training needs 
identified, and enhance the training capacity of these training institutes within the 
framework of a national training network; 
(vi)  ensure  that  training  modules  and  training  curricula  are  standardized  and 
consistent with microfinance best practices through consultations in the national 
training network, and ensure that training materials developed under the project 
are widely accessible within the network, including on the websites of ADB, the 
SBV, and other partners, in the form of printouts readily available for interested 
parties; and 
(vii)  prepare progress reports on the activities detailed above and provide inputs to 
assist the team leader in preparing the inception, quarterly progress, midterm, 
draft final, and final reports, as required by the team leader. 
 
4.  Microinsurance specialist (4 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will have a 
postgraduate  degree  in  banking  or  finance  or  a  development-related  subject  and  at  least 
7 years of recognized professional experience in training, microfinance, micro insurance, and 
project  management.  Experience  in  Southeast  Asia,  especially  knowledge  of  Viet  Nam’s 
insurance  and  microfinance  industry,  is  desirable.  Working  with  the  team  leader,  the 
microfinance training specialist, and the PMU, the micro insurance specialist will: 
 
(i)  formulate the implementation plan and strategy for mounting a financial literacy 
roadshow on microinsurance focusing on raising awareness and advocating the 
promotion and development of the microinsurance industry in Viet Nam;  
(ii)  in  coordination  with  the  MOF  Insurance  Supervisory  Authority  and  the  key 
stakeholders  in  microinsurance,  develop  and  formulate  appropriate  market 
conduct guidelines for microinsurance;

Appendix 3  11 
(iii)  develop appropriate advocacy training modules and advocacy materials to be 
used in mounting the insurance literacy roadshow; 
(iv)  conduct  a  series  of  advocacy  trainings,  seminars,  and  workshops  for  key 
stakeholders to promote the microinsurance industry in Viet Nam; 
(v)  conduct  appropriate  seminars  and  workshops  for  concerned  MOF  Insurance 
Supervisory Authority officers and staff to enhance their supervisory capacity for 
microinsurance; 
(vi)  assess  and  consolidate  the  training  needs  of  the  key  stakeholders  in 
microinsurance.  Develop  a  training  plan  and  coordinate  to  engage  partner 
training  institutes  in  the  delivery  of  practical  training  courses  tailored  to  the 
training needs identified, and to enhance the training capacity of these training 
institutes within the framework of a national training network; and 
(vii)  prepare progress reports on these activities and provide inputs to assist the team 
leader in preparing the inception, quarterly progress, midterm, draft final, and 
final reports, as required by the team leader. 
 
B.   National Consultants 
 
5.  Microfinance  specialist  (9  person-months,  intermittent).  The  specialist  will  have  a 
degree  in  banking  or  finance  or  a  related  discipline  and  at  least  4  years  of  professional 
experience in retail microfinance. Reporting to the team leader and working with the PMU, the 
specialist will:  
 
(i)  assist the team leader with all aspects of the terms of reference as required; 
(ii)  collect and analyze required data and information, and make them available in 
English in an organized, readable form; 
(iii)  provide  written  and  oral  translation  from  English  to  Vietnamese  and  from 
Vietnamese to English as required, including in meetings and workshops; 
(iv)  assist in the preparation of guidelines, mandates, manuals, and procedures, as 
required; 
(v)  assist in the provision of day-to-day support to participating MFIs in implementing 
their  transformation  and  operational  expansion,  and  in  introducing  and  pilot-
testing innovative products and services; 
(vi)  assist  in  providing  day-to-day  support  to  the  PMU  for  project  management, 
including on-the-job mentoring for SBV staff on all aspects of MFI operations and 
supervision, as necessary; 
(vii)   undertake  other  tasks  necessary  for  efficient  TA  implementation,  including 
translation and interpretation, as may reasonably be required; and 
(viii)  contribute as required to the inception, quarterly progress, midterm, draft final, 
and final reports. 
 
6.   Microfinance  training specialist  (6 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will 
have a degree in banking or finance or a related discipline and at least 4 years of professional 
experience in microfinance. Prior training experience is required. Reporting to the international 
microfinance training specialist and working with the PMU, the national specialist will:  
 
(i)  assist the international specialist with all aspects of the terms of reference as 
required; 
(ii)  collect and analyze required data and information, and make them available in 
English in an organized, readable form;

12  Appendix 3 
(iii)  provide  written  and  oral  translation  from  English  to  Vietnamese  and  from 
Vietnamese to English as required, including in meetings and workshops; 
(iv)  assist in planning, preparing, and delivering all required training workshops; in 
coordinating with partner microfinance training institutes; and in ensuring training 
material quality and availability, as required; 
(v)  assist in providing individual training and day-to-day support to meet the specific 
training  requirements  of  participating  MFIs,  including  on-the-job mentoring of 
board members, managers, and staff on all aspects of microfinance operations; 
(vi)  undertake  other  tasks  necessary  for  efficient  TA  implementation,  including 
translation and interpretation, as may reasonably be required; and 
(vii)  contribute as required to the inception, quarterly progress, midterm, draft final, 
and final reports. 
 
7.  Project assistant (12 person-months, intermittent). The assistant will have a degree in 
banking  or  finance  or  a  development-related  subject  and  at  least  4  years  of  recognized 
professional  experience  in  project  assistance  and  management.  Experience  working  for 
international aid organizations is preferable. The assistant will:  
 
(i)  assist in arranging and organizing meetings for TA activities and ADB missions; 
(ii)  assist in preparing materials for reports, meetings, and workshops, including 
translating materials and document production; 
(iii)  provide  written  and  oral  translation  from  English  to  Vietnamese  and  from 
Vietnamese to English as required, including in meetings and workshops; 
(iv)  provide assistance to TA consultants on specific technical matters as requested; 
(v)  provide assistance to TA consultants on administrative matters including travel 
and visa arrangements, maintaining hard and soft copies of files including for 
backup, and general office administration; 
(vi)  contribute as required to the inception, quarterly progress, midterm, draft final, 
and final reports; and 
(vii)  perform  other  work  in  connection  with  the  project  as  may  be  reasonably 
requested by TA consultants.
